learning_outcomes.description: Define a research problem, state a research hypothesis, and plan a process for the investigation of the problem.

Integrate the practical experience gained in previous years of study to develop a novel process, product, analyse the various aspects of food and nutrition topics; OR undertake fundamental studies, and research data recording.
Design and implement a research project/survey; OR undertaking a substantial critical literature review.
Analyse, process, and interpret research data.
Present experimental results and draw relevant statistical conclusions.
Write a thesis in an approved format.
Deliver an oral presentation of a research project.

assessments.task_description: Before the first Thursday of Teaching Week 1, the student needs to have approval from an academic supervisor for a research project. A form will need to be completed by both the student and supervisor and emailed to the course coordinator before the first Thursday of Week 1.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to submit a research proposal and experimental protocol to their primary project adviser to allow assessment and feedback of progress with respect to their level of scientific technical planning, writing skill, knowledge depth and coverage, and comprehension.

The research proposal guidelines are below and can also be found attached, and under Course Files on the Blackboard site.

Structure of a Research Proposal (~2000 words)

1. Introduction to the topic

2. Hypothesis

3. Aims and Objectives

4. Methodology

5. Timeline (GANTT Chart)

6. References (APA 7th)

Introduction (30%)

Aims, research questions and hypotheses.

Short literature review.

Relevant theory is described briefly.

Clear and concise statements explaining the rationale for the research are provided.

The rationale is both understandable and convincing.

The proposal contains clear and concise statements of research aims, objectives and hypotheses.

The research question logically follows from the extant literature and addresses a meaningful gap or debate in the field.

Methods (40%)

The methods and materials are appropriate to answer the research question and the study design and are reliable and valid.

The description of the procedure is thorough, logical, coherent, and in sufficient detail to enable replication.

All stages involved in conducting the research are clearly described, and the approach is feasible.

The analysis strategy (can be statistics or other relevant analysis) is clearly described and optimal in addressing the research question(s).

Limitations of the approach are considered and addressed.

Gantt chart (20%)

Thoughtful and realistic timeline; incorporates all necessary tasks for project completion.

Presentation (10%)

Spelling and grammar are appropriate, visual aids (figures, graphs, tables, etc.) are suitable for the project under consideration, the format has been followed correctly, and the correct reference format using APA 7th.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submissions, independent of AI or MT tools. The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.

Week 26 Mon - Week 26 Fri

assessments.task_description:
Presentation consisting of a 10 minute presentation and 5 minutes of questions.

The following format of presentation is recommended.

1. Title page - 1 slide

2. Outline - 1 slide

3. Background - aims, hypothesis and objectives - 1 slide

4. Materials and methods - 2 slides

5. Results - 4 slides

6. Conclusion and recommendation for further research - 1 slide

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools. The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.

assessments.assessment_title: Research Project Final Report and Performance
assessments.task_description:
See final report format recommendations (manuscript structure) below and on the Blackboard site. An example of a manuscript is also available on the Blackboard site.

The final report should be written and formatted as a peer-reviewed manuscript for submission to a scientific journal consisting of approximately 7000 to 8000 words. The report should demonstrate the student’s ability to conduct scientific research and communicate their findings clearly and professionally.

Start by selecting a reputable journal in your research field. Review the journal's author guidelines carefully and adhere to its specific formatting, citation style, and submission requirements.

Use the structure outlined below as guidance for preparing the manuscript and adhere to the formatting guidelines outlined by the selected journal to ensure the manuscript aligns with the requirements of academic publishing.

1.  Manuscript Structure

Your manuscript must include the following sections:

Title Page

  • Title: A concise and informative title that accurately reflects your study.
  • Author(s): Include your name(s) and institutional affiliation(s).
  • Corresponding Author: Provide an email address for correspondence.

Abstract (250–300 words)

  • Provide a brief summary of the research, including the background, objectives, methodology, key findings, and conclusions.
  • Use clear and concise language without references or citations.

Keywords (3–6 keywords)

  • Select relevant keywords that reflect the key themes of your research.

Introduction

  • Introduce the research problem and its significance.
  • Provide a review of the relevant literature to contextualise your study.
  • State the research objectives and hypothesis (if applicable).

Materials and Methods

  • Describe the experimental design, materials used, and procedures followed in sufficient detail for reproducibility.
  • Include any ethical considerations or permissions obtained.
  • Specify analytical techniques, software, and statistical methods used.

Results

  • Present your findings in a logical sequence.
  • Use tables, figures, and graphs to communicate your data effectively.
  • Avoid interpreting results in this section.

Discussion

  • Interpret your results in the context of existing literature.
  • Discuss the implications of your findings, limitations of your study, and potential future research directions.
  • Ensure your discussion aligns with your research objectives.

Conclusion

  • Summarize your main findings and their significance.
  • Avoid introducing new data or concepts.

References

  • Use a consistent citation style as directed by the journal guidelines (e.g., APA 7th or the journal’s preferred format).
  • Include all references cited in the text.

Supplementary Materials (if applicable)

  • Include any additional data, figures, or appendices that support your study.

2.  Additional Guidelines

  • Use a formal, scientific tone throughout your manuscript.
  • Write in the third person and past tense for the methods and results.
  • Formatting:
  • Use Times New Roman, 12 pt as font
  • Use double spacing.
  • Number the pages and include section headings.
  • For those students who have difficulty in deciding what page format to use, the following is a suggestion:
  • Margins: Top 3 cm, Bottom 3 cm, Left 3 cm, Right 3 cm.
  • Paragraphs: Left justified, Right unjustified, Indent first line by 1.5 cm.
  • Figures and tables:
  • Figures and tables should be appropriately labelled and referenced in the text.
  • Include clear, descriptive captions for all figures and tables, positioned either above (tables) or below (figures) the item.
  • Proofreading:
  • Carefully proofread your report for grammar, spelling, and formatting errors before submission.
  • Submit your proof to your supervisor to receive feedback on how to improve your thesis before submission.

Student Performance Marking

The advisor's mark is an objective assessment by the student's advisor(s) as to the overall quality of the student in terms of their scholarship, practical competence and potential for independent post-graduate research. This assessment will be guided by adherence to the scientific practice of maintaining a laboratory/field record by means of regular entries into a Laboratory Notebook.

Project activities must be recorded each week in the Lab Notebook, with at least 1 page of the book allocated for each week of activities. 

A Laboratory Notebook is available to students at the start of their course. Upon completing the research project, the student must transfer all project-related data, records, documentation, and relevant materials to their primary academic supervisor. This includes both raw and processed data, laboratory notebooks, electronic files, reports, and any other project outputs or records generated during the course of the research. The student and supervisor have to sign a declaration as a formal confirmation that the project data and information transfer have been completed, and this document has to be submitted to the School of Agriculture and Food Sustainability Student Services by the due date, together with the Thesis. This is a compulsory requirement to pass the course.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools. The use of AI or MT must be referenced appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.

learning_activities.topic:
Laboratory safety induction

All students need to undertake the Health and Safety Inductions and carry out online training before commencing their projects.

Laboratory safety training sessions for research project students are scheduled fortnightly and hosted via Zoom. 

All students will need to:

  1. Receive a site induction with their Supervisor or delegate. This must include emergency evacuation exit, assembly area, first aid stations, first aid officer and nearest Defibrillator.
  2. Complete a paper based New Worker induction checklist with their supervisor and email to sciohs@uq.edu.au.
  3. Complete Training Needs Analysis for all workers (TNA) with their supervisor. Email these to sciohs@uq.edu.au once complete.
  4. Complete mandatory online training (identified in the TNA) as soon as possible (i.e. Fire Safety training) through either workday or blackboard.
  5. Complete Training Needs Analysis for Lab workers (TNA-lab) with their supervisor. Email these to sciohs@uq.edu.au once complete.
  6. Attend a Faculty of Science HSW Safety Training Session

  

To enrol in a Faculty of Science HSW Safety Training Session. To register or email sciohs@uq.edu.au .

Learning outcomes: L01

learning_activities.topic:
Experimental work

Students will conduct their research projects under the guidance of their supervisor.

All experimental activities must be documented in the laboratory notebook provided by the School of Agriculture and Food Sustainability.

Each student must submit their completed and supervisor-signed laboratory notebook directly to Student Services by the due date, along with their thesis.

Submission of a signed laboratory notebook that clearly records the experimental work carried out during the project is a compulsory requirement to pass the course.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
